prelate counſayled hym ſayd muſt nedes behoue hym hūble hym ſelfe frenche kynge vncles duke ſayde well content ſo ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe ſir helion lignacke made reporte duke berrey howe lordes scotlande aſſembled toguyder cytie berdane determyned reyſe vp army entre englande englyſſhe ſquyer takenne scottes knewe ſecretneſſe bothe realmes englande scotlande cap c xl counſayle byſſhoppe trect aduyſe byſſhoppe colonge ye byſſhoppe laege ſente french kynge treate ye duke iulyers kynge approched paſſed nat two thre leages daye trayne great bytwene morſay oure lady amount duke berey route mo fyue hundred ſperes lodged thyder came duke berrey ſir helyon lignacke ſir wyllyam brother sir wyllyam came fro ſiege vanchadore duke ſente hym duke burbone ſente ſir iohan boeſme launce lefte ſtyll ſiege companyes lefte capitaynes ſir iohan butlere ſir loyes dambier ſir helyon lignacke came gaſcon fro bayon fro duke lancaſtre duke berrey made hym good chere demaunded tidynges sir helyon ſhewed hym ſayd sir kyng caſtyle ſeketh duke lancaſtre haue peace hym treateth ſore haue ſone prince wale marry duke doughter worde duke berrey penſyfe ſayd sir helion yet ſhall ſende one agayne knowe certayne byſſhoppe poycters tyme haue ynoughe alſo ſame weke lorde coucy retourned fro auygnon came kyng ardane euery man glad cōmynge ye haue herde howe kynge richarde englande ſome trouble agaynſt vncles vncles agaynſt hym dyuers incydentes duke irelande many knyghtes englāde deed beheeded archebyſſhop yorke brother lorde neuell poynte haue loſte benefyce newe counſaylers kyng arch byſſhoppe caunterbury lorde neuell ben chiefe ruler kepar fronters northumberlande agayſt ſcottes fyue yeres togyder put wage euery yere ſixtene thouſande frankes countie yorke byſſhoprike durham ſette ſtede lorde henry percye hadde wage yere xi thouſande frankes wherof lordes lygnage thoughe kynne yet hadde therat great enuy indignacyon one agaynſt another knewe ryght well ſcottes lordes knyghtes scotlande determyned one agayne reyſe vp army make iourney englande ſayde good tyme houre ſawe englyſſhmen nat one accorde often tymes paſt receyued great buffettes ſayd good tyme reuenged entent purpoſe ſhulde nat knowen ordayned feeſt holden fronter wylde ſcottes cytie called berdane aſſembled maner lordes scotlande feeſt concluded made full promyſe myddes auguſt yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred fourſcore ano eight ſhulde mete puyſſaunce fronters gale caſtell hyghe foreſt called gedeours thus tyme departed eche fro couenaūt none made kyng priuy therto ſayd amonge themſelfe kyng manne warre came gedeours day apoynted firſt erle iames duglas ſir iohan morette erle marche donbare ſir wyllyam de fu ſir stephyn erle monſtres ſir aucebauce duglas ſir robert auerceque ſir marke odremneu ſir wyllyam lymſey ſir iames brother thomas berry ſir alyſaunder lymſey lorde sechyn ſir iohan sobelas ſir patryke dōbare ſir iohn̄ senclere ſir patryke hoteborne ſir iohan ſonne ye lorde momogomercy ſir adam glaſ diuyn ſir wyllyam reduryn ſir wyllyam stonacke ſir iohn̄ halpe breton ſir alider ſir robert lander ſir stephyn freſeyle ſir alyſander ramſey ſir iohan brother ſir wyllm̄ morbereth ſir maubert ſir wylliam waleran ſir iohn̄ amonſtan dauy ſonne robert colemney dyuers knightes ſquiers scotlande threſcore yere nat aſſembled toguyder scotlande ſuche nombre good mē xii hūdred ſpeares xl thouſande men beſyde archer ī tyme nede ſcottes lytell ſkyll bowes rather beare ax wherwith gyue great ſtrokes whan thus mette togyder marcheſſe gedeours mery ſayd wolde neuer entre againe owne houſes tyll ben englande done ſuche dedes ſhulde ſpoken xx yere entent make ſure poyntment aſſigned daye mete churche fayre laūde called zedon tidynges came northumberlande nothynge hydde men putte dilygence knowe bothe therle chyldrē ſeneſchall yorke ſir mathue redman capitayne berwike gret feeſt ben bredane thērent knowe wherfore theſe lordes ſente ſertche couertly heraudes mynſtrels ſcottes coude nat mater ſo ſecrerly ye lordes englāde knewe howe men roſe ſcotlāde ſhulde mete agayne gedeours brute came newcaſtell vpontyne whan lordes knewe euery man toke good hede charge prouyded ſelfe redy aſſemble nede dyde ſecretly bycauſe enterprice ſhulde nat broken euery man helde hym ſelfe owne houſes determyned mete toguyder ſoone knewe ſcottes came forwarde ſayd ſcottes come forthe ſhall haue knowlege therof drawe towardꝭ carlyle ſhall entre another parte countrey ſhall dommage v countrey open maye go lyſt countre ſtrong townes caſtelles well cloſed better knowe ſtate ſcottes ſent gentylman englā de knewe ryght well marcheſſe scotlande ſpecially foreſt gedeours ye ſcottes ſhulde aſſemble engliſſhe ſquyer went ſo forwarde without eſpyeng came churche zedon ſcottyſſ lordes encred amonge lyke one ſeruauntes herde knewe great parte thententes ſcottes thende counſayle ſquyer went tree hadde tyed horſe thought haue foūde gone ſcotte great theues ſtollen hym awaye durſte nat ſpeke hym ſo went forthe fote boted ſpurted whan gone fro churche two bowe ſhotte two ſcottyſſ knyghtes deuyſed bytwene ſelfe ſayd one another felowe haue ſene marueyle beholde yonder man gothe alone thynke hath loſt horſe came ſpake worde wene none company lette v ryde hym proue ſayeng rode hym ſoone ouertoke hym whan̄e ſawe cōmynge wolde gladly haue ben then came hym demaunded whether wolde whens came done horſe began varry ſayeng anſwered nat directely purpoſe turned hym ſayde ſhulde go ſpeke lordes brought hym churche zedon preſented hym erle duglas lordes examyned hym parceyued well englyſſhe man ſayde wolde knowe trouthe came thyder yuell wyllynge ſhewe trouthe handled hym ſuche wiſe fayne ſhewe mater bare hym hande withoute wolde ſhewe trouthe incōtynent ſhulde leſe heed wolde ſhewe trouthe ſhulde haue none yuell knew hym lordes northumberlande ſente hym thyder knowe eſtate ent̄price whiche waye wolde drawe herof ſcottes right ioyous wolde nat great good ſpoken ſquyer demaunded agayne hym parte englyſſhe lordes whyder aparence wolde aſſemble toguyder way • wolde take entre scotlande outher ſee ſyde berwyke el donbare el highe waye countie monſtres towarde streuelyn ſquyer anſwered ſayde sir ſithe behoueth ſay trouthe ſhall whan departed fro newcaſtell none aparence aſſemblyng redyneſſe departe well daye morowe ſoone knowe ye ſet forwarde entre englande wyll nat come mete nat ye power ſo fyght ſythe ye ſo great nombre ſayd englande ye quod erle moret nombre repute v sir quod ſayd howe ye xl thouſande men xii hundred ſpeares ſir ye take waye gale wyll go berwike ſo donbare edenborome el alqueſt ye take nat waye wyll go carlyle mountayns yt countrey whan lordes herde eche regarded englyſſhe ſquyer putte kepyng conſtable gedeours cōmaunded ſhulde ſurely kepte ſame place wente agayne counſayle lordes scotlande ryght ioyfull knewe ſurely entent ennemyes demaunded counſayle waye beſt take mooſt wyſeſt beſt experte warre ſpake fyrſt ſir archanbas duglas therle fenne ſir alyſander ramſey ſir iohan saynt clere ſir iames lymſey ſayd feare faylynge entent counſayle make two armyes entente ennemyes ſhall nat knowe whervnto attende lette mooſt parte hooſt caryage go carleon galles lette company thre four hū dred ſpeares two thouſāde well horſed drawe towardes newcaſtell vpon tyne paſſe ryuer entre byſſhorike durham burne exyle countrey ſhall make great breull englande ennemyes prouyded weſe folowe v wyll lette v drawe oure companyes toguyder take good place fyght doute nat ſhall haue honoure lette v reuenged dommages haue done v counſayle accepted ordayned ſir archanbas duglas therle fenne erle surlancke erle monſtres erle mare therle aſtroderne ſir stephyn freſeyle ſir george donbare ſirtene great lordes scotlande ſhulde lede mooſt parte armye towardes carlyle erle duglas ſir orge erle mare donbare erle iohan morette theſe thre capitaynes thre hundred ſpeares choſen men two thouſande men archer go towardes newcaſtell entre northūberlande thus theſe two hooſtes departed eche eche prayenge englyſſhmen folowed armyes nat fyght tyll bothe armyes ioyned toguyder thus mornyng departed fro gedeours toke feldes ⸪ ¶howe erle duglas wanne penon ſir henry percy barryers newcaſtell vpontyne howe ſcottes brente caſtell pondlen howe ſir henry percy ſir rafe brother toke aduyſe folowe ſcottes conquere agayne penone loſt ſcrimyſſhe cap c xli whan̄e englyſſhe lordes ſawe ſquier retourned agayne tyme apoynted coud knowe nothynge ſcottes dyd purpoſed thought well ye ſquyer taken lordꝭ ſent eche redy whan ſoeuer ſhulde ſcottꝭ brode meſſanger thought hym loſt ¶nowe lette v ſpeke erle duglas wente carlyle whan erles duglas moret de la mare donbare departed fro great hooſt toke waye thynkyng paſſe water entre byſſhoprike durham ryde ye towne retourne brinnyng exyling countrey ſo come newcaſtell lodge towne diſpite englyſſhe men determyned ſo ſo dyde aſſaye putte vre rode great paſe vnder couert doyng pyllage waye aſſautyng caſtell towre houſe ſo came lorde percyes lande paſſed ryuer tyne without let thre leages aboue newcaſtell nat farre fro braſpathe laſt entred biſſhoprike durham founde good countrey beganne make warre ſlee people brinne vyllages many ſore diſpleaſures tyme erle northumberlande lordes knyghtes countrey knewe nothyng cōmyng whan tidynges cāe newcaſtell durham ſcottes abrode myght well ſe fiers ſmoke abrode countrey erle ſente newcaſtell two ſonnes ſente commaundemente euery man drawe newcaſtell ſayenge ſonnes ye ſhall go newcaſtell countrey ſhall aſſemble ſhall tary nymyche whiche paſſage muſte paſſe may encloſe ſhall ſpede well sir henry percy ſyr rafe brother obeyed father cōmaundement came thyder countrey ſcottes rode burnynge exylynge countrey ſmoke therof came newe caſtell ſcottes came gate durham ſkrymyſſhed taryed nat longe returned ordeyned founde waye toke diſtroyed bytwene durham newcaſtell twelue leages englyſſh good countrey towne without cloſed brente repaſſed ryuer tyne paſſed came newcaſtell reſted englyſſhe knyghtes ſquyers countrey yorke byſſhoprike durham aſſēbled newecaſtell thyder came ſeneſchall yorke ſir rafe mombraye ſyr rafe redmayne capytayne berwyke ſir roberte angle ſyr thomas grey ſir thomas holcon ſir iohan felton ſyr iohan lyerborne ſyr thomas abyton baron helcon ſir iohan copuldyke dyuers ſo towne ſo full people wyſt nat lodge whan theſe thre ſcottyſſhe erles chyefe capytaynes made enterpriſe byſſhoprike durham ſore ouer rynne countrey retourned newcaſtell reſted taryed two dayes euery day ſkrymyſſhed erle northumberlandes two ſonnes two yonge luſty knyghtes euer formaſte barryers ſkrymyſſhe many proper feates armes done archyued fyghtynge hande hande amonge fought hande hande erle duglas ſir henry percy force armes erle duglas wanne penon ſyr henry percyes wherwith ſore dyſpleaſed ſo englyſſhmen erle duglas ſayd ſir henry perey ſyr ſhall beare token prowes scotlande ſhall ſette hyghe caſtell alqueſt may ſene farre syr quod ſir henry ye maye ſure ye ſhall nat paſſe boundes countrey tyll ye met withall ſuch wyſe ye ſhall make none auaunte therof well ſyr ꝙ erle duglas come nyght lodgynge ſeke penon ſhall ſette lodgynge ſe ye wyll come take away late ſcottes withdrewe lodginges refreſſhed ſuch fleſhe ynough made nyght good watche thought ſurely waked wordes hadde ſpoken nat ſyr henry percy counſayled nat ſoo nexte day ſcottes dyſlodged returned towardes owne countrey ſo came caſtell towne called pouclan wherof ser haymon alphell lorde ryght good knyght ſcottes reſted came thyder tymes vnderſtode knyght caſtell ordeyned aſſayle caſtell gaue great aſſaute ſo force armes wan knyght within towne caſtell brent fro then scottes wente towne caſtell combur eyght englyſſhe myle fro newe caſtell lodged day made none aſſaut next mornyng blewe horne made redy aſſayle caſtell whiche ſtronge ſtode mareſſe daye aſſauted tyll wery dyd nothynge ſowned retrayte retourned lodgyng lordes drewe counſayle determyne ſhulde moſte parte acorde next day ſhuld dyſſoge without gyuynge aſſaute drawe fayre eaſly towardes carlyle therle duglas brake counſayle ſayd diſpyte ſir henry percy ſayd wolde come wynne agayne penon let v nat departe hence two thre dayes lette v aſſayle caſtell prignable ſhall haue double honour lette v ſe wyll come fetche penon ſhall well defended euery man acorded ſayeng honour loue hym alſo lodged eaſe none troubled theym made many lodgynges bowes great herbes fortityed campe ſagely mareſſe therby caryages ſette entre mareſſes beeſtes within mareſſe aparelled ſaute next day entenſyon nowe lette v ſpeke ſir henry percy ſir rafe brother ſhewe ſome dyd ſore dyſpleaſed therle duglas wonne penon armes alſo touched gretly honour dyd nat ſyr henry percy ſayd wolde ſayd erle duglas ſhulde nat cary penon englande alſo openly ſpoken fore knyghtes ſquiers newcaſtell englyſſhmen thought ſurely therle duglas bande ſcottes vangarde hooſt lefte behynde knyghtes countrey ſuche well experte armes ſpake agaynſt ſir henry percyes opinyon ſayd hym syr fortuneth warre often tymes many loſſes erle duglas haue wonne penon bought dere came gate ſeke well beaten another day ye ſhall wynne moche hym syr ſaye bycauſe knowe well power scotlande abrode feldes iſſue nat men ynowe fyght peraduenture haue made ſkrimyſſhe v entent drawe v towne nombre ſayd aboue xl thouſande men maye ſoone incloſe v v wyll yet better leſe penon two thre hundred knyghtes ſquyers put countrey aduenture theſe wordes refrayned ſyr henry brother wolde nothynge agaynſt counſayle tydynges came theym ſuche ſene scottes ſene demeanoure waye toke reſted ¶howe ſyr henry percy brother good nombre men armes archer went ſcottes wynne agayne penon erle duglas hadde wonne newcaſtell vpon tyne howe aſſailed ſcottes mountberke lodgynges cap cxlii ſhewed ſir henry percy broder knightes ſquyers ſuche folowed ſcottes fro newecaſtell well aduyſed doynge ſaid ſir henry ſyr rafe syrs haue folowed ſcottes priuely haue diſcouered countrey ſcottes pountclan haue taken ſyr haymon alphell owne caſtell fro thence gone ottenburge laye nyght wyll morowe knowe nat ordayned abyde ſirs ſurely great hooſt nat paſſe nat thre thouſāde men whan ſir henry herde ioyfull ſayd syrs let v leape horſes faythe iowe god lorde father wyll go ſeke penon dyſlodge theym ſame nyght knyghtes ſquiers herde agreed therto ioyous euery man made hym redy ſame euenynge byſſhop durham came thyder good company herde durham howe ſcottes newcaſtell howe lorde percy ſonnes lordes knightes ſhulde fight ſcottes therfore byſſhoppe dutham come reſkewe aſſembled vp countrey ſo comynge newcaſtell ſir henry percy wolde nat abyde comynge hym ſyre hundred ſpeares knightes ſquiers eight thouſande fotemen thought ſufficyent nombre fyght ſcottes nat thre hundred ſpeares thre thouſande thus departed fro newcaſtell dyner ſet forth good ordre toke ſame way ſcottes gone rode ottebourge ſeuen lytell leages fro thence fayre way coulde nat ryde faſte bycauſe fotemen whan ye ſcottes ſupped ſome layde downe reſt wery trauaylynge ſautynge caſtell day thought ryſe erly mornyng cole day gyue newe aſſaute therwith ſodenly englyſſhmen came entred lodginges wenyng ben maiſters lodgynges therin varlettes ſeruauntes englyſſhmen cryed percy percy entred lodgynges ye knowe well ſuche affray noyſe ſone reyſed fortuned well ſcottes whan ſawe englyſſhmen came wake lordes ſente certayne ſeruauntes fotemen ſkrymyſſhe englyſſhmen entre lodgynges ye meane tyme armed aparelled euery man vnder baner vnder capytaynes penon night farre mone ſhone ſo bryght ben maner daye moneth auguſt wether fayre temperate thus ſcottes drawen gyder without noyſe departed fro lodgynges went aboute lytell mountayne whiche greatly aduauntage day well aduyſed place ſayd amonge ſelfe englyſſhemen come v ſodaynly wyll thus thus ioperdous thyng nyght men warre entre lodgynges wyll drawe ſuche place therby outher ſhall wyn leſe whan englyſſhmen entred felde firſt ſoone ouercame varlettes entred alwayes foūde newe men beſy ſkrymyſſhe ſodaynly came ſcottes fro aboute mountayne ſette englyſſhmen ware cryed cryes wherof englyſſhe menne ſore aſtonyed cryed percy partye cryed duglas began cruell batayle fyrſt encountre many ouerthrowen bothe partyes bycauſe engliſſhmen great nombre greatly deſyred vanquyſſhe enemyes reſted pa greatly dyd put backe ſcottes ſo ſcottes nere dyſcomfyted erle iames duglas yonge ſtronge great deſyre gette prayſe grace wyllynge deſerue haue cared payne trauayle came forthe baner cryed duglas duglas ſir henry percy ſyr rafe brother great indygnacion agaynſt erle duglas bycauſe wonne penon armes barryers newcaſtell came parte cryed percy two baners mette menne ſore fyght englyſſhmen ſo ſtronge fought ſo valyauntly reculed ſcottes backe two valiaunt knightes ſcottes vnder baner erle duglas called ſyr patryke helborne ſyr patryke ſonne acquyted ſelfe day valy auntly erles baner ben nat ben defended ſo valyauntly reſcuynge therof dyd ſuche feates armes greatly recommendacyon heyres euer ſhewed ſuche ſame batayle well knyghtes ſquyers englande scotlande houſe erle foiz anone batayle done met ortays two ſquyers englande called iohan newecaſtell iohan cauteron alſo whan retourned fro auignon founde alſo knyght ſquyer scotlande knewe knewe byſuche token ſhewed countrey auctor boke youthe rydden nygh ouer realme scotland fyftene dayes houſe erle wyllyam duglas father ſame erle iames whome ſpake nowe caſtell fyue leages fro edenboro win countrey alqueſt ſame tyme ſawe erle iames fayre yonge chylde ſuſter called lady blaunche enfourmed bothe theſe party batayle ſore batayle fought lyghtly hath harde ſuche nombre beleue well englyſſhmen one partye ſcottes party good men warre whan mete harde ſight without ſparynge hoo bytwene longe ſpeares ſwordes are dagers wyll endure lay eche vpon whan well beaten one parte hath optaygned victory glorifye ſo dedes arme • ſo ioyfull ſuche taken ſhall raunſomed go • elde ſo ſhortely eche ſo contente deparrynge curtoyſly wyll ſaye god thanke fyghtynge one another playe ſparynge trewe ſhall well apere ſayd rencountec valyauntly foughten coulde deuyſed ye ſhall ⸪ ⸪ ¶howe erle iames duglas valyātneſſe incouraged men reculed maner diſcomfyted ſo doynge wounded dethe cap cxliii knyghtes squyers good corage bothe party fyght valyauntly cowardes place hardynes rayned goodly feates armes knyghtes ſquiers ſo ioyned gyder hande ſtrokes archer place nother party ſcottes ſhewed great hardyneſſe feught meryly great deſyre honour englyſſhmen thre one howe ſay nat englyſſhmen dyd nobly acquyte ſelfe euer englyſſhmen rather ben ſlayne taken place flye thus haue ſayd baners duglas percy men met eche againſt enuyous ſhulde wynne honoure iourney begynnynge englyſſhemen ſo ſtronge • eculed backe enemyes erle duglas great harte hygh enterpriſe ſeynge men recule backe recouer place ſhewe knightly valure toke bothe handes entred ſo ye preaſe made hym ſelfe waye ſuche wyſe none durſte aproche nere hym ſo well armed bare well ſuche ſtrokes receyued thus wente euer forwarde lyke hardy hector wyllynge lone conquere felde dyſcomfyte enemyes laſte encountred thre ſpeares one one ſtrake hym ſhulder breſte ſtroke glented downe bely thyrde ſtrake hym thye ſore hurte thre ſtrokes ſo borne perforce erthe coulde nat agayne releued knyghtes ſquyers folowed hym nat nyght lyght ſhynynge mone engliſſhmen knewe well borne one downe erth wyſt nat knowen ben erle duglas therof ſo ioyfull ſo prowde vyctory alſo ſcottes knew nat aduenture tyll ende batayle knowen ſhulde haue ſo ſore dyſpayred dyſcoraged wolde haue fledde awaye thus erle duglas felled erth ſtriken heed axe another ſtroke throughe thye englyſſhe men paſſed tooke hede hym thought none otherwyſe 〈◊〉 hadde ſlayne man armes parte erle george de la •• donbare fought ryght valyantly gaue engliſſh men moche cryed folowe duglas ſette ſonnes percy alſo erle iohan morette baner men fought valyauntly ſette fyerſly engliſſhmen gaue ſo moche wyſte nat whome attende ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe batayle ſir rafe percye ſore hurte taken pryſoner ſcottyſſhe knyght cap cxliiii bataylles encountrynges haue made melicion hyſtory great ſmalle batayle treate nowe one ſoreſt beſt foughten without cowardes faynte hertes nother knyght ſquyer dyde deuoyre fought hande hande batayle lyke batayle bechercll whiche valyauntly fought endured erle northumberlandes ſonnes ſir henry ſir rafe percy chefe ſouerayne capytayns acquyted ſelfe nobly ſir rafe percy entred ſo farre amonge enemyes cloſed hurte ſo ſore handeled brethe ſo ſhorte taken pryſoner knyght erle morettes called ſir iohan makyrell takynge scottyſſhe knyght demaunded nyght ſo knewe hym nat ſyr rafe ſo ſore ouercome bledde faſt laſte ſayd rafe percy ſcotte ſayde ſyr rafe reſkewe reſkewe take priſoner makyrell well quod ſir rafe contente take hede ſore hurte hoſen greues full blode knyght ſawe hym erle moret ſayde syr delyuer ſyr rafe percy priſoner ſir lette good hede taken hym ſore hurte erle ioyfull thoſe wordes ſayd makyrell thou haſt well wonne thy ſpurres delyuered ſyr rafe percy certayne men ſtopped wrapped woundes ſtyll batayle endured nat knowynge better many taken reſkewed agayne came knowledge nowe let v ſpeke yonge iames erle duglas dyd maruayls armes beaten downe whan ouerthrowen preace great ſo coulde nat releue axe dethes woūde men folowed nere coulde came hym ſyr iames lymſey coſyn ſyr iohan ſir water ſaynt clere knyghtes ſquiers hym gentle knyght folowed day chapelayne nat lyke preeſt lyke valyaunt man armes night folowed erle good handes ſtyll ſkrymyſſhed aboute erle lay reculed backe ſome engliſſhe men gret ſtrokes gaue thus founde fyghtynge nere mayſter wherby hadde great prayſe therby ſame yere made archedecon abredan preeſt called ſyr willyam norbernyche tall man hardy ſore hurte whanne theſe knyghtes came erle founde hym yuell caſe knyght lyenge hym called ſir roberte harte fyftene woundes one place ſyr iohan sayncte clere demaunded erle howe dyd ryght yuell coſyn quod therle thanked god hath fewe myne auncytours hathe dyed beddes coſyn requyre thynke reuenge recon ſelfe deed herte faynteth often tymes coſyn water praye rayſe vp agayne baner whiche lyeth grounde ſquyer dauy collemnie ſlayne ſyrs ſhewe nother frende ſoo caſe ye ſeme myne enemyes knewe wolde reioyſe frendes diſcomforted two bretherne saynt clere ſir iames lymſcy dyd erle hadde deſyred theym reyſed vp agayne baner cryed duglas suche behynde herde crye drewe togyther ſet enemyes valyauntly reculed backe englyſſhe men many ouerthrowen ſo draue englyſſhe men backe beyonde place erle laye tyme deed ſo came erles baner whiche ſyr iohan saynte clere helde handes many good knyghtes ſquyers scotlande aboute hym ſtyll company drewe crye duglas thyder came erle morette baner well accompanyed alſo erle de la mare donbare whan ſawe engliſſh men recule cōpany aſſembled togyder renewed agayne batayle gaue many harde ſadde ſtrokes ¶howe ſcottes wanne batayle agaynſt englyſſhe men beſyde otteburge taken priſoners ſir henry ſir rafe percy howe englyſſhe ſquyer wolde nat yelde wolde ſcottyſſhe ſquier ſo dyed howe byſſhope durham company diſcomfyted amonge themſelfe ca c xlv ſaye trouth englyſſhmen ſorer trauayled ſcottes came ſame day fro newcaſtell vpon tyne ſire englyſſh myles went great paſe entente fynde ſcottes whiche dyd ſo faſt goynge nere brethe scottes freſſhe well reſted greatly auayled whan tyme buſyneſſe laſte ſkrymyſſhe reeuled backe englyſſhemen ſuche wyſe coude aſſemble togyther ſcottes paſt batayles fortuned ſir henry percy lorde mountcombre valyaunt knyght scotlande fought togyther hande hande ryght valyauntly without lettynge euery man ynough longe two fought perforce armes ſyr henry percy taken priſoner ſayde lorde mountcomber knyghtes ſquiers scotlande ſir mare adremench ſir thomas auerneſquyn ſyr willyam ſyr iames ſir alyſander lymſey lorde faulcon iohan ſaynte de laur ſyr patryke donbare ſir iohan ſyr water saynte clere ſir iohan makyrcll ſir guyſtewarde ſyr iohan halebreton ſyr alyſaunder ramſey roberte colounnie two ſonnes iohan roberte made knyghtes hundred knyghtes ſquyers nat name theſe ryght valyauntly dyd acquyte ſelfe englyſſhe parte lorde percy taken fought valyauntly ſyr rafe longeble ſyr mathewe redman ſyr thomas ogle ſir thomas gray ſir thomas hekon ſir thomas abreton ſir iohan lyerbon ſir willyam walſyngham baron helcon ſir iohan culpedup ſeneſchall yorke dyuers fotemen wherto ſhould write longe proces ſore batayle well foughten fortune alwayes chaungeable though engliſſhmen nombre ſcottes ryght valyaunt men warre well experte fyrſte fronte reculed backe ſcottes yet fynally ſcottes optaygned place vyctory foreſaid englyſſhmen taken hundred mo ſauynge ſir mathewe rodman capytayne berwyke whan knewe remedy recoueraunce ſawe company flye fro ſcottes yelded theym euery ſyde toke horſe departed ſaue hym ſelfe ſame ſeaſon aboute ende dyſcomfyture englyſſhe ſquyer called thomas veleton goodly valyant man well ſene nyght wolde nother flye yet yelde hym ſayd made vowe feeſt englande firſt tyme euer ſawe engliſſhe men ſcottes batayle wolde ſo deuoyre power ſuche wyſe eyther wolde reputed beſt doer bothe ſydes el dye payne called valyaunt hardy man dyd ſo moche prowes vnder baner erle morette dyd ſuche valyauntneſſe armes ſcottes hadde maruayle therof ſo ſlayne fyghtynge ſcottes wolde gladly haue taken hym alyue wolde neuer yelde hoped euer haue reſcewed ſcottyſſhe ſquier ſlayne coſyn kynge ſcottes called symon glaudyn dethe greatly complayned ſcottes batayle fierſe cruell tyll came ende diſcomfyture whan ſcottes ſawe englyſſhmen recule yelde thēſelfe ſcottes curtes ſette theym raunſome euery manne ſayde pryſoner syrs go vnarme take youre caſe mayſter ſo made priſoners good chere though ben brother without doyng thē dōmage chaſ •• ndured fyue englyſſhe myles ye ſcottes men ynowe none ſcaped outher ben taken ſlayne archambault duglas erle fen erle surlant great cōpany gone towardes carlyle ben lykelyhode taken byſſhoppe durham ye towne newcaſtell vpon tyme ſhall ſhewe howe ſame euenyng percyes deꝑted fro newcaſtell ye haue herde byſſhop durham rerebande cāe newcaſtell ſupped ſatte table ymagmacion hym ſelfe howe dyd nat acquite hym ſelfe well ſe englyſſhe men felde within towne incontynent cauſed table taken away cōmaunded ſadell horſes ſowne trū pettes called vp men towne arme ſelfe mount horſes foote men order ſelfe departe thus euery man departed towne nombre ſeuyn thouſande two thouſande horſebacke fyue thouſande fote toke waye towarde ottenbourg batayle ben tyme hadde gone two myle newcaſtell tidynges came theym howe men fightynge ſcottes ther byſſhoppe reſted incontynent came mo flyeng faſte brethe demaū ded howe mater wente aunſwered ſayde right yuell diſconfyted cometh ſcottes chaſynge v theſe tidynges troubled englyſſhmen began doute agayne thirde tyme men came flyeng faſt might whan̄e men byſſhoprike durham herde theſe yuell tidynges abaſſhed ſuche wiſe brake array ſo byſſhoppe coude nat holde togyder nombre fyue hūdred thought ſcottes folowed nombre ſeyng night thentryng towne engliſſh men ſo abaſſhed towne ben byſſhope durham beyng felde good wyll haue ſocoured englyſſhmen recōforted men aſmoche coude ſawe owne men flye well demaunded couſaile ſir wyllyam luſſey ſir thomas clyfforde knyghtes beſt theſe knyghtes honoure wolde gyue hym counſayle thought retourne agayne nothyng ſhulde ſowne greatly blame go myght great dō mage ſo ſtode ſtyll wolde gyue none anſwere lengar ſtode fewer ſome ſtyll ſtale awaye byſſhoppe ſayd sir thynges conſidred none honour putte parell make one yuell dommage twayne howe company diſconfyted nat remedy go recouer knowe nat wt nombre ſhall mete lette v retourne fayre eaſely night newcaſtell lette v drawe toguyder go loke enemyes euery man anſwered god wyll ſo therwith retourned newcaſtell thus man maye conſyder great defaute men yt abaſſhed diſconfyted kepte togyder haue turned agayn ſuche fledde diſconfyted ſcottes opynion dyuers bycauſe dyde nat thus ſcottes vyctorie ¶howe ſir mathue reedman deꝑted fro batayle ſaue hym ſelfe howe ſir iames lymſaye taken priſoner byſſhoppe durhame howe bataile ſcurrers ſente forthe diſcouer countrey cap cxlvi shall ſhewe ſir mathewe reedman horſbacke ſaue himſelfe alone coude nat remedy mater departynge ſir iames lymſay nere hym ſawe howe ſir mathue deꝑted ſir iames wyn honour folowed chaſe ſir mathue reedman came ſo nere hym myght haue ſtryken hym ſpeare lyſt ſaid ah ſir knyght tourne ſhame thus flye iames lymſay ye wyll nat tourne ſhall ſtryke backe ſpeare sir mathewe ſpake worde ſtrake horſe ſpurres ſorer dyde maner chaſed hym thre myles laſte ſir mathue reedmans horſe founvred fell vnder hym ſtepte forthe ye erthe drewe oute ſwerde toke corage defende h • mſelfe ſcotte thought haue ſeryken hym breſt ſir mathewe reedman ſwarued fro ſtroke ſpeare poynt entred erthe ſir mathue ſtroke ſonder ſpeare ſwerde whan ſir iames lymſay ſawe howe loſte ſpeare caſte awaye tro • chon lyghted fote toke l • tell bacayle caryed backe handeled one hande quickely delyuerly whiche feace ſcottes well experte ſette ſir mathue defended hym ſelfe properly thus tourneyed toguyder one ſwerde longe ſeaſon man lette fynally ſir iames lymſay gaue knyght ſuche ſtrokes helde hym ſo ſhorte putte brethe ſuche wyſe yelded hym ſelfe ſayde sir iames lymſay yelde well quod receyue reſcue reſcue content quod reedman ſo ye deale lyke good companyon ſhall nat fayle ꝙ lymſay ſo putte vp ſwerde well ſir ꝙ reedman wyll nowe ſhall priſoner ye haue conquered wolde gladly go agayn newcaſtell within fyftene dayes ſhall come scotlande ye ſhall aſſigne cōtent quod lymſay ye ſhall promyſe faythe preſent ſelfe within iii wekes edē borowe ſoeuer ye go repute yourſelfe priſoner ſir mathue ſware promyſed fulfyll eche toke ho • ſes toke leaue eche 〈◊〉 sir iames returned entent go owne cōpany ſame way came ſir mathewe reedman newcaſtell sir iames lymſaye coulde nat kepe ryght waye came darke myſt hadde nat rydden halfe myle met face face byſſhoppe durham mo v hundred englyſſhmen hym might wel eſcaped wolde ſuppoſed owne cōpany purſued englyſſhmen whan among thē one demaunded hym quod ſir iames lymſay byſſhoppe herde thoſe wordes ſtepte hym ſaid lymſay ye taken yelde ye quod lymſay ꝙ byſſhop durham fro whens come ſir ꝙ lymſay come fro batayle ꝙ byſſhop ſtroke neuer ſtroke 〈◊〉 backe newcaſtell night ye ſhal go maye nat choſe quod lymſay ſithe ye wyll haue ſo haue taken taken ſuche aduentures armes haue ye taken quod byſſhop ſir quod toke chaſe ſir mathue redman quod byſſhop faythe ſir retourned newcaſtell deſyred truſt hym faythe thre wekes ſo haue done well ꝙ byſſhop lette v go newcaſtell ye ſhall ſpeke hym thus rede newcaſtell toguyder ſir iames lymſay priſoner biſſhop durham vnder baner therle de la mare dōbare taken aſquer gaſcone called iohn̄ newcaſtell vnder baner erle moret taken companyon iohn̄ de cauteron thus felde clene auoyded daye apered ſcottes drewe togyder toke guydes ſente ſcurrers ſe men waye fro newcaſtell entent wolde nat troubled lodgynges wherin dyd wiſely whan ye byſſhop durham come agayne newcaſtell lodgynge ſore pēſyfe wyſt nat ſaye herde ſay howe coſyns ye percy ſlayne taken ye knightes yt thē ſent ye knyghtes ſquyers towne whan come demaunded thē ſhulde leaue mater caſe ſayde sir ſhall beare great blame thus retourne without lokynge oure ennemyes cōcluded ſonne ryſynge euery manne armed horſ backe foote departe towne go octenbourge fyght ſcottes warned towne trumpet euery man armed theym aſſembled bridge ſonne ryſynge departed gate towardes berwyke tooke waye towardes octebourge nombre tenne thouſande foote horſe backe nat gone paſte two myle fro newcaſtell whan ſcottes ſygnefyed byſſhoppe durham commynge theym warde fyght knewe ſpyes ſuche ſette feldes ſir mathewe reedman retourned newcaſtell hadde ſhewed dyuers howe taken priſoner ſir iames lymſey ſhewed hym howe biſſhoppe durham hadde taken ſayd ſir iames lymſey towne priſoner ſoone byſſhoppe departed ſir mathue reedman wente byſſhoppes lodgyng ſe mayſter founde hym ſtudye lyeng wyndowe ſayd ſir iames lymſay make ſir iames came forthe ſtudy hym gaue hym good morowe ſayd faythe ſir mathewe fortune hathe brought hyder ſoone departed fro mette chaunce ye byſſhoppe durham whome priſoner ye beleue ye ſhall nat nede come edenborowe make fynaunce thynke rather ſhall make exchaunge one another byſſhoppe ſo contente well ſir quod reedman ſhall accorde ryght well toguyder ye ſhall dyne daye byſſhop men gone forthe fyght men nat tell ſhall fall ſhall know retourne content dyne quod lymſay thus theſe two knyghtes dyned toguyder newcaſtell whan knyghtes scotlāde enformed howe byſſhop durham came x thouſande men drewe counſayle ſe beſt outher deꝑte el abyde aduē ture thynges conſydred concluded abyde ſayd coude nat better ſtronger place alredy many priſoners coulde nat cary theym awaye ſhulde haue departed alſo hadde many men hurte alſo ſome priſoners whōe thought wolde nat leue behynde thus drewe toguyder ordred ſo felde ther entre one waye ſette priſoners toguyder made promiſe howe reſcue reſcue ſhulde priſoners made mynſtrels blowe vp atones made greatteſt reuell worlde lightlye vſage ſcottes whan thus aſſembled toguyder armes foote men bereth neckes home maner lyke hunter ſome great ſome ſmall ſortes ſo whan blowe one make ſuche noyſe may herde nighe iiii myles thus abaſſ enemyes reioyſe ſelfes whan byſſhoppe durham baner xm men hym aproched leage ye ſcott • blewe horne ſuche wiſe ſemed deuyls hell amonge ſo ſuche herde knewe nat vſage ſore abaſſhed blowyng noyſe endured longe ſpace ceſſed tyme thēglyſſhmen within leſſe myle ye ſcottes began blowe agayn made great noyſe long endured dyd byſſhop aproched batayle well rainged ī good order came within ye ſyght ye ſcottes within ii bowe ſhot leſſe ye ſcottes blewe horne lō ge ſpace ye byſſhop ſtode ſtyll ſe ſcottes wolde auewed thē well ſaw howe ſtronge grounde greatlye aduauntage byſſhop tooke counſayle beſte hym thynge well aduyſed nat purpoſe entre amonge ſcottes aſſayle retourned withoute doyng thyng ſawe well myght rather leſe wyn whan ſcottes ſawe englyſſhe men recule ſhulde haue batayle wente lodgynges made mery than̄e ordayned departe fro then bycauſe ſir rafe percy ſore hurte deſyred maiſter myght retourne newcaſtell ſome place pleaſed hym vnto ſuch tyme hole hurtes promyſynge ſonne able ryde retourne scotlande outher edenborowe place apoynted erle mare vuder taken agreed therto delyuered hym horſe lytter ſent hym waye lyke couenaunt dyuers knyghtes ſquyers ſuffred returne tooke terme outher retourne el paye fynaūce ſuche apoȳ ted vnto ſhewed informacyon ſcottes ſuche ſayd batayle bytwene newcaſtell octeburge yere lorde god thouſande thre hundred fourſcore viii xix daye auguſt nowe yt taken priſoners engliſſhe partie xl men one ſlayne felde chaſe xviii hundred xl ſore hurte mo thouſande ſcottes hundred ſlayne taken chaſe mo two hundred englyſſhmen fledde whan ſawe aduautage retourned agayne fought meanes ſcottes taken none otherwyſe euery man maye well conſydre well fought felde whan ſo many ſlayne taken bothe party ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe ſcottes departed caryed therle duglas deed buryed hym abbey nimays howe ſir archambault duglas company departed fro carlyle retourned scotlande cap cxlvii batayle thus furnyſſhed euery man retourned erle duglas deed body cheſted layde chare hym ſir robert hart symon glaudyn prepared departe departed ledde ſir henry percy mo xl knyghtes englande tooke waye abbey nimay de partynge ſette fyre lodgynges rode daye yet lay night englyſſhe grounde none denyed thē nexte daye diſlodged early mornyng ſo came daye nimay abbey blacke monkes border bytwene bothe realmes reſted buryed erle iames duglas ſeconde daye obſequye done reuerētly body layde tombe ſtone baner hangyng ouer hym wheder mo erles duglas whome lande retourned nat nat tell ſir iohn̄ froiſſart auctour boke scotlande ye erles caſtell alqueſt lyueng erle wyllm̄ whiche tyme two chyldren ſonne dought many duglaſſes haue ſene av bretherne ſquiers bearyng ye name duglas ye kyng scotlādes houſe dauid ſōnes knight scotlāde called ſir iames duglas bare armes golde thre oreyls goules ye herytage knowe nat ſir archambalt duglas haue ſpoken hyſto • ie dyuers place valyant knight gretly redouted englyſſhmen baſtarde whan theſe ſcottes hadde ben nymaye abbey done came thyder departed eche fro wente owne countreis ſuche hadde priſoners ſome ledde awaye ſome raūſomed ſuffred returne thus englyſſhe men founde ſcottes right curteſſe gentyll delyueraunce raunſome ſo well contente ſhewed countrey bierne erle foiz houſe knyght named iohan newcaſtell taken priſoner ſame iourney vnder baner erle mare donbare greatly prayſed ſayd erle ſuffred hym paſſe maner deſyred hym ſelfe thus theſe men warre scotlande departed raunſomed priſoners ſoone myght ryght curtteſly ſo retourned lytell lytell owne countreis ſhewed beleue well ſcottes reaſon iourney two hundred thouſande frankes raunſomyng priſoners ſythe batayle streuelyne scotlande ſir robert breuce ſir wyllyam duglas ſir robert verſey ſir symon freſeyle ſcottes chaſed englyſſhmen thre dayes neuer iourney ſo ꝓfytable ſo honorable thē whan tidynges came company ſcottes beſyde carlyle howe company diſtreſſed englyſſhe men beſyde octeburgh greatly reioyſed diſpleaſed myndes nat ben determyned diſlodge drawe owne countreys ſeynge company withdrawen thus diſlodged entred scotlāde ¶nowe lette v leaue ſpeke ſcottes englyſſhe men tyme lette v retourne yonge charles fraunce great people wente almaygne bringe duke guerles reaſon whan frenche kynge armye paſte ryuer mueſe bridge morſay tooke waye ardayn luſenbourgh alwayes pyoners beatynge woodes buſſhes makynge wayes playne duke iulyers countrey greatly douted comyng frenche kynge knewe well ſhulde haue fyrſt aſſault beare fyrſt burdone lande iulyers playne coūtrey one day men warre ſhuld moche dōmage diſtroye waſt excepte caſtelles good townes thus frenche kyng entred coū trey luſenbourgh came abbey vyncelant ſomtyme duke brabant buryed kyng taryed two dayes departed toke waye throughe baſconque lodged within leage duches brabant laye • e ſent worde beyng ye duke burgoyn brought felde ſpeke kynge receyued right honourably cōmuned togyder duches retourned baſconque thyder ſhe conueyed ſir iohn̄ vyen ſir guy tremoile next daye kyng went forwarde aprochyng lande enemyes came thē cryng almayne fronters ye duchy iulyers came ſo far forwarde arnolde biſſhop liege ye kyng greatly entreated duke iuliers kyng ſhulde nat miſcontent hym though father duke guerles excuſed hym deflaūce ſonne made affyrmyng nat knowlege conſent wherfore ſayd pytie father ſhulde beare defaut ſonne excuſe nat ſuffycient kyng vncles entent kyng coūſayle without ye duke iulyers wolde come make maner excuſe yelde hym ſelfe ye kynges pleaſure countrey ſhulde firſt ſhulde beare burdone thanne byſſhoppe liege lordes haſbane counſayls good townes offred kynge counſayle holly byſſhoprike liege armye paſſe repaſſe payeng expenſes reſt refreſſhe long pleaſed kyng thanked ſo dyde vncles wolde nat refuſe offre knewe nat nede ſhulde haue ⸪ 〈1 page duplicate〉 〈1 page duplicate〉 ¶howe duke iulyers came excuſed hym ſelfe defyaū ce ſon̄e duke guerles made frenche kyng ſo became ſubiecte dyuers feates armes done bytwene frenchman almayns rencongne cap cxlviii thus biſſhoppe liege retourned duke iullyers archebyſſhoppe coloigne ſhewed thē done thervpon toke aduyſe duke iuliers great dout cryling waſtyng countrey ſent knightes countrey haue counſayle aduyſe dayly frenchman aproched lorde coucy ye vowarde hym thouſande ſpeares duke lorayne hym vicount meaulx two hūdred ſpeares whan frenche men aproched fronters almayne rode toguyder good order lodged wiſely thre hūdred ſpeares lynſars almayns beyond ryuer ryne gathered toguyder noted greatteſt pyllers robber worlde alwayes purſued cooſted frenchman fynde diſpurueyed dōmage frenche men douted ſame durſt neuer go • forragyng great companyes vnderſtode ſir boucequant elder ſir loyes grache retayned brought nimay theſe ſayd almayns rode alwayes couertly lyke byrdes flyeng ye ayre ſekyng praye made frenche men wyſe well ware thus whan frenche kyng come ſo forwarde entre duchy iulyers duke iulyers wolde nat leſe countrey beleued coūſayle archebyſſhoppe coloyne byſſhop liege theſe two entreated hym ye kynge brought mater poynt lādes reſt peace meanes ſuche condycions foloweth theſe two prelate dyde ſo moche yt brought duke iulyers kynges preſēce vncles duke lorayne great lordes fraunce ye blode royall whan kyng kneled downe wiſely excuſed defyaūce ſonne made ſayd howe ſonne foole neuer counſayle hym dyde dyde owne wyll offred ye kyng ſayeng sir entent bring hym ye knowledgynge reaſon lycence wyll go hym ſhewe hym folly quickely counſayle hym cōe make excuſe youre grace counſayle wyll nat thus agaynſt counſayle ſhall abandon townes caſtels countrey prouyde men warre make warre againſt hym tyll ye haue taken hym mercy kyng regarded brother vncles coūſaile ſemed hym offre faire reſonable ſo thought dyuers kyng toke vp duke iulyers kne whyle ſpake kyng ſayd hym sir ſhall take counſayle aduyſe promyſes wordes duke roſe vp ſtode ſtyll byſſhoppes brought hym thyder kyng vncles ſuche ſecrete counſayle drewe toguyder debated mater long dyuers opiniōs duke burgoyne principallye mater touched bicauſe duchy brabant wherin chalēged haue great right enherytaunce dethe duches iane bycauſe lady margaret wyfe alſo ſay trouthe chiefe cauſer kynges cōmyng thyder yt puiſſaūce wherfore wolde euery thyng might beſt thentent good peace might made bitwene ꝑties ſhulde occaſyon cōe thyder agayne another tyme bycauſe voyage long coſtly realme ſayd kyng sir lyke grace brother berrey ſaye thynges yuell begone lyeth great aduyſe howe coſyn duke iulyers greatly exſcuſeth hymſelfe ſo valyant man blode ought beleue hym offereth kyng great thyng body countrey townes caſtelles kynges cōmaundemente caſe ſonne duke guerles wyll rebell come nat make amendes defyaunce hath made ſpeke acordynge reaſon great thynge haue v duke iuliers duke guerles ſhall feble eaſyer correcte ſhall dought v ſoner come obeyſaunce wherfore counſayle offre nat refuſed mekely humyleth hymſelfe greate lordes almayne entreate hym theſe wordes contrary opynyons conſented one acorde byſſhoppes coloygne liege called counſayle ben chyefe entreatours buſynes declared fro poynte poynte frome clauſe clauſe thynges ye duke iulyers ſhulde ſwere ſeale wolde haue landes ſaued reſte fyrſt ſhulde go ſonne duke guerles ſhewe hym playnely foly great outrage done ſende defye ſo puyſſaūt prince frenche kynge ſpecially ſuche fell defyaunce ſtyle ryght reaſon cauſe come reaſon mercy wolde nat thus abyde ſtyll opynyon feble wytte counſayle duke iulyers ſwere ſeale renounce hym fro ayde ſocoure myght become enemy ſuffre ſuche ſhall apoynted kynge counſayle abyde wynter lye garyſons countrey iulyers make frounter warre agaynſt duke guerles well entreated receyued theſe two prelate called kinges counſayle entente ſhulde ſhewe duke iulyers theſe artycles ſo dyd duke ſawe well howe behoued hym agree el haue landes ouer tynne waſted wherfore acorded ſware ſealed vpholde kynges deſyre ſo lande ſhulde nat ouerron exyled contente lande ſhulde vytayle armye thus duke iulyers became frenche kynges man made relyefe lande vierſon beyng bytwene bloys berrey ſupped nyght kynges table fyrſte ſate byſſhoppe liege byſſhoppe coloygne kynge duke burgoyne duke thowrayn duke iuliers duke burbone thus duke iulyers reſte peaſe foreſayd meanes kynge armye lodged countrey whiche pleaſaunt plentyfull vytayles duke iulyers wente towardes duke guerles ſonne came dyuers feates armes done countrey almayns couetouſe oftentymes night daye wolde ieoparde ſelfe ſette frenche men lodgynges kepe wakynge ſomtyme wanne ſome tyme loſt one almayne taken euer four frenchman taken daye conſtable fraunce lorde coucy duke lorayne marſhall blainuill ſir iohan vien ſyr iohan de la tremoyle four thouſande men armes came towne guerles called renconge ſhewed ſelfe good ordre batayle ſame tyme ye duke guerles within towne prayſed moche demeanour made none iſſue nat men ynowe wherof ryght ſore dyſpleaſed thus frenche men good ordre batayle ſpace four houres whan ſawe none wolde iſſue departed returned lodgynges ſame euenynge duke berreys lodgyng certayne knyghtes ſquyers drewe togyther entent ryde forthe mornynge lande enemy ſeke ſome aduenture promyſed eche ſtycke togyther lyke bretherne nombre aboute hundred ſpeares whan mornynge came purpoſe broken ſquyer auuergne called godinos valyaunt man armes pertayned lorde alegre whan ſawe refuſed company wolde nat deſyre hym go ſore dyſpleaſed brake mynde nother ſorte companyons ſo nombre thyrty ſpeares tode forthe togyther rode mornynge coulde fynde none adventure whan godynos ſawe ſhulde retourne without doynge feate ſore dyſpleaſed ſayde company syrs ryde fayre eaſely page wyll ryde aboute wode ſe enbuſſhe hydden therin tary vpon yonder mountayne agreed hym thus page rode forthe coſtynge wode whan rydden lytell waye herde one ſtell wode ſtrake horſe ſportes came ſyde wode founde almayne guetloys cuttynge wode godynos toke glay • e came ry • nynge man wherof man ſore abaſſhed godynos made ſygne hym ſhulde go thought companyons yet ſhulde ſe founde ſomwhat thought ſame manne ſhulde ſome ſeruyce lodgynges ſo godynos rode lowe hackeney almayne folowed hym foote hewynge axe necke wherwith wrought wode godinos page lepte mayſters courſer bare baſſenette ſpeare folowed halfe ſlepynge bycauſe ryſen ſo early almayn knewe nat whyder ſhuld go wolde hym thought delyuer hymſelfe came fayre eaſely godynos lyfte vp ſtrake hym ſuche ſtroke heed claue teth ſo ouerthrewe hym ſtarke deed page knewe nat therof tyll ſawe mayſter fall vyllayne fledde wode ſaued hymſelfe aduenture fell godinos wherwith ſuche knewe hym ſore dyſpleaſed ſpecyally auuergne man armes moſte doughted engliſſhmen thoſe party dyd moſt domage priſone ſhulde haue ben quyted twenty thouſande frankes ¶nowe lette v retourne duke iulyers ¶howe duke iuliers archebyſſhop coloygne departed fro frenche kynge wente nymay duke guerles howe meanes reconſyled brought peace frenche kynge duches brabante cap cxlix ye knowe well hathe ben ſhewed howe duke iulyers made peace frenche king meanes byſſhoppes treated behalfe alſo ſaye trouthe duke lorayne coſyn toke great payne mater ye haue herde duke promyſed go ſonne duke guerles cauſe hym come kynges mercy el make hym warre thus duke iulyers fayne promyſe el countrey ben loſte thus duke iulyers archbyſſhoppe toke iourney go guerles paſſed ryuer came nymay duke receyued father great ioye bounde nothynge ſo nere man father mother nothynge glad herde howe duke father agreed frenche kynge duke iuliers byſſhop ſhewed hym length hole mater caſe lande ſtode made lytle therof ſo ſore alyed kynge englande wolde nat forſake hym herte good englyſſhe ſo excuſed hym ſelfe greatly ſayde father ſyr let alone wyll abyde aduenture take domage reaſon frenche kynges comynge yonge ynough beare reuenged herafter ſome parte realme fraunce vppon neyghbours brabanſoys lorde canne kepe warre without ſome domage ſometyme leſe ſometyme wynne whan father duke iulyers herde hym ſo ſtyffe opynyon ſore dyſpleaſed ſayd sonne willyam whome make youre warre ſhall reuenge domage syr quod kynge englande puyſaunce haue gret maruayle tydynges englyſſhe army ſee come haue promyſed wolde haue wakened frenche men oftener thanne one tyme quod father truſt abyde englyſſhmen ſo beſyed euery quarter wote nat whome entende duke lancaſtre coſyn lyeth bayon burdeaux retourned spayne ſmall ordre hath loſt men tyme hath ſente englande haue mo men armes archer nat get nombre xx ſpeares alſo englyſſhe men haue late playne batayle great domage northumberlande chyualry aboute newcaſtell vpon tyne ouerthrowen ſlayne taken ſo nowe realme englande nat good quyete reſte wherfore nat truſt tyme englyſſhe men ye ſhall haue comforte wherfore coūſayle ruled v ſhall make peace frenche kyng ſhall ſo moche ye ſhall nouther receyue ſhame domage syr quod duke guerles howe may myne honoure acorde frenche kynge though ſhulde leſe hole lande go dwell ſome place ſurely wyll nat ſore alyed kinge englande alſo haue defyed frenche kynge thynke feare hym ſhulde reuoke wordes breke ſeale ye wolde ſhulde dyſhonored requyre let alone ſhall defende ſelf right well agaynſt ſet lytell thretenynges water raynes colde wether ſhall ſo fight tyme ianyuer come ſhall ſo wery hardyeſt theym ſhall wyſſhe ſelfe home owne houſes thus begynnynge treatie duke iuliers byſſhoppe coloyne coulde nat breke duke guerles purpoſe yet hym ſixe dayes euery day counſayle whan duke iulyers ſawe otherways began ſore argue againſt ſonne ſayd sonne ye wyll nat byleue ſurely ſhall dyſpleaſe enherytaunce duchy iulyers ye ſhall neuer haue one foote therof rather ſhall gyue ſtraunger ſhall puyſſaunce defende agaynſte ye foole ye wyll nat beleue counſayle whan duke guerles ſawe father inflamed ire apeaſe diſpleaſure ſayd sir counſayle myne honour deſyre ſhall leane therto ſyr iowe obeyſaunce wyll duke iulyers ſayde sonne nowe ye ſpeke ye ſhulde ſhall loke honoure aſmoche wolde myne owne deuyſed great delyberacion counſayle ſaue honoure party duke guerles ſhulde go frenche kynge hym honoure reuerence ought kynge make excuſe defyaunce ſente kynge ſay maner syr trewe letter tyme ſealed ſeale ſente fraunce whiche came knowledge whiche letter contaygned defyaunce pertaynynge grace realme wordes vnreaſonable ryght ſtyle vſage prince lordes defie eche whiche wyll nat auowe ye euer ſuche wordes paſſed mouthe cōmaundemente worde touchynge defamynge name ſignory ſyr veryfye myne excuſe trouthe maye ſuſpecte ſhall declare trouthe euery thynge syr reaſon great alyaunce ſeruyce haue borne ryght redouted lorde kynge englande requeſte counſayls ſente englande four knyghtes delyuered theym ſeale ſeale thynge concluded vpon ſealed letter nat neuer knewe ſealynge letter conteyned therin syr requyre grace accepte excuſe trewe ſir aliaunce ſeruyce haue made lorde kynge englande wyll neuer breke contrarye commaundeth ſyr requeſt cōmaundement wyll defye whan ſhall pleaſe hym ſo euer except myne owne naturall lorde kynge almayne whome made ſeruaunte mouthe ſpoken myne handes ſyr honoure conſyderynge recompenſynge paynes traueyls ye haue ſuſteyned iourney comynge hyder knowe foundacion trouthe defyaunce ſhall ſwere kepe ſhal neuer make warre agaynſt defye fyrſte ye ſhall ſignyfyed therof hole yere ſir thynke ſhulde ſuffyce deuyſe duke guerles ſayde well contente thus dyſhonour blame thynke thus poynte departed duke iulyers ſonne duke guerles archebyſſhoppe coloygne ſo returned iulyers came endeſker whan tyme wente frenche kynge ſhewed poyntes artycles reherſed ſayd syr loke ye wyll duke guerles ye ſhall nat haue hym frenche kynge greatly deſyred ſe duke guerles coſyn cauſe put hym ſomoche payne wherfore ſoner enclyned treatye duke burgoyn wolde alſo duches brabant countrey ſhulde byde reſt peace toke payne bringe creatie effecte yt duke guerles myght come ſpeke kynge alſo one thynge made ſoner agre wynter aproched nyghtes began longe colde alſo lordes fraunce enfourmed guerles countrey reſt tyme wynter alſo dayly reporte howe loſte men bothe knyghtes ſquyers ſynſars almayns dayly lay wayte many reaſons conſyderacyons layde alledged fell acorde duke guerles aproched duke iulyers father duke lorayne byſſhop coloigne brought hym kynges tente kynge thre vncles brother duke tourayne duke bare erle marche erle ſaynte pole erle dolphyn auuergne lorde coucy conſtable fraunce duke guerles kneled downe kynge infourmed kyng toke hym vp valyauntly wyſely exſcuſed hym ſelfe defyaunce made kynge moreouer ſware euer wolde defye kynge make warre realme fraunce wolde gyue kynge knowlege therof yere countreys guerles brabante ſtyll ſame caſe ſame preſēt tyme thus mater concluded bytwene duke guerles ſupped kynge ſame nyghte table greatly regarded bycauſe put kynge ſo moche payne coſte treatie concluſyon put writynge ſealed whan done lordes toke leaue departe departed duke guerles demaunded kynge ſuche priſoners frenche men taken warre myght haue delyuered franke free deſyre delyuered thanne kynge demaunded duke ſuche pryſoners men taken voyage ſhulde delyuered rendred agayne duke guerles excuſed hym ſelfe ſayde syr poore man whan knewe commynge fortifyed ſelfe beſt myght men warre knyghtes ſquyes fro beyonde ryuer ryne place promyſed ſo euer wanne warre ſhulde owne wherfore take nothinge fro haue wonne wolde haue nouther puyſſaunce power wolde ſhewe rygoure theym wolde make warre agaynſt wherfore ſir may pleaſe lette paſſe canne nat remedy kynge ſawe coulde haue nothyng el ſuffred paſſe imagyned realme riche ynough encreaſe poore men wherfore let paſſe ſpake mo wordes departure eche theym well contented ordeyned dyſlodge retourne ſame way came ſayd frenche kynge ſhulde cytie reynes feeſt ſayntes holde great feeſt thus euery man dyſlodged retourned ¶nowe lette v ſpeke englyſſhe army ſee ⸪ ⸪ ¶howe erle arundell knyghtes englande beyng ſee fortune wynde came palyce beſyde rochell whoſe beynge ſignifyed ſir loys xanſer departynge erle arundell cap cl meane ſeaſone whyle french kyng guerles englyſſhe army ſee wherof erle arundell chefe capytayne ſome tyme ſayled forwarde ſomtyme bacwarde wynde wolde ſerue ſeke aduentures well knowen always lightly bytwene feeſt ſaynt remey ſayntes peryllous ſeaſon ſtormes wyndes ſee aboute ſame tyme roſe ſuche tempeſte ſperkled abrode englyſſhe nauy ſuche wyſe hardyeſt marynere ſore abaſſhed ſo perforce conſtreyned ſeke lande erle arundell xxvii veſſelles hym whether wolde nat fayne caſte ancre lytell hauen called palyce two ſmall leages fro rochell ye wynde ſo ſtreynable ſee borde coude nat departe thence whanne tydynges therof came rochell great dought fyrſte leſte engliſſhmen wolde come great domage cloſed gate helde ſhytte day halfe tydynges came fro palyce howe englyſſhemen xxvii veſſelles came thyder force wynde wether taryed nothynge de parte agayne erle arundell lorde henry beamonde ſir willyam helmen mo thyrty knyghtes englande rochell tooke counſayle thynge beſte thyng conſydered ſayd howe ſhulde eaſly acquyte themſelfe went nat ſkrymyſſhe ſame ſeaſon caſtell bouteuyll ſyr loys xanſere merſhall fraūce beſieged within fortreſſe gylliam ſaynt foye gaſcon marſhall great company poicto • xayntone piergourt rochell lowe march nat gone almayne ye knig ſir loys ſoueraygne capytayne ouer fronters bytwene mountpellyer rochell tyll retourne lorde coucy rochell ſent worde marſhall englyſſhmens beynge palyce whan herde therof ryght ioyfull ſent theym ſhulde make redy ſeuen eyght galees man forthe wolde come lande fyght engliſſhmen rochell dyd commaunded ſir loys departed fro ſiege brake vp thought ſhulde honorable hym fyght erle arundell englyſſhe men rather thanne contyne ſtyll ſiege thus wente rochell knyghtes ſquyers folowed hym nat tell inſpyracyon erle arundell knowledge howe marſhall fraunce greate puyſſaunce knyghtes ſquyers comynge fyght hym palyce whiche tydynges nat pleaſaunte erle arundell howe wynde ſome layde ſee aueyled erle wayed vp ancres ſayled ſee ſuche good ſeaſon taryed longe encloſed hauen euery man taken contynent thyder came galees rochell well manned furnyſſhed artyllery gonne came ſtreyght hauen palyce foūde engliſſhe men departed purſued two leages ſee ſhotte gonne howebeit durſt nat longe folowe feare enbuſſhmentes ſee frenche ſhippes returned marſhall fraunce ſore dyſpleaſed theym rochell ſente hym worde ſo late erle arundell toke waye ryuer garon come burdeaux therby ye ſiege bowteuyll defeated gillonet ſaynt foy prouyded garyſon neded meane tyme ye marſhall went fyght englyſſhe men nowe let v retourne ſomwhat ſpeke duke lancaſtre howe treatie ſpanyardes alſo duke berrey maryage doughter kynge caſtyle treated hym ſonne prince caſtyle entent haue peace engliſſhe men alſo duke berrey treated haue duke lancaſters doughter hymſelfe great deſyre maryed duke lancaſtre lyke ſage imagynat •• e prince ſawe well howe profitable englande hym mary doughter caſtyle rather duke berrey therby thought recouer herytage caſtyle tyme come doughter ſhulde gyue duke berrey duke fortune dye doughter ſhulde poore lady regarde bycauſe duke berrey chyldren fyrſt wyfe ſhulde haue profyte alſo ducheſſe lancaſtre enclyned kynge caſtyles ſonne whan ſir helyon lignac departed fro duke lancaſtre retourned duke berrey beynge almayne king caſtyls meſſāgers well herde ſuche wyſe wordes noted offer accepted couenaunte made ſworne bytwene kateryn lancaſtre kynge caſtylles ſonne writynges publike inſtrumentes oblygatory bondes made concluded • le repentaunce yt duches lācaſtre euery thyng ſet ordre ſhulde bring doughter kateryn caſtyle ſeaſon frenche kynge ſtyll fronters iulyers concludynge duke guerles ye haue herde howe departed frenche men retourned fortuned fronteres almayne nyght aboute mydnyght mone • hone fayre certayne almayns robber pyllers dyd ſette nother peace warre alwayes ſought aduauntage ſome pertaynynge lorde blaqueneuen ſir peter conebech well horſed came aduyſed french hooſt might haue moſt profyte aduauntage ſo paſſed lodgyng vycount meaulx ſawe ſtyringe returned without noyſe makynge outher paſſynge retournynge came agayne enbuſſhe ſhewed ſene founde • incontynente theſe almayns came entred aduauntage frenchman lodgynges ouerthrewe nat tell howe many toke xiiii menne armes priſoners taken lorde vieſuile lorde mountkarell aduenture frenche men hadde ſame nyght reaſon made eaſy watche yuell ordred next day whan theſe tydinges knowen howe lorde vieſuille lorde mountkarell taken frenche men ſore diſpleaſed toke better hede whan frenche kynge departed fro countrey iulyers none taryed behynde euery man drewe garyſons ſir guylliam tremoyle ſir geruays furrande braban ſoys waye euery man wente home retournynge frenche men ordeyned great delyberacion coūſayle frenche kynge ben vnder gouernynge vncles euer ſyth dethe laſte kynge father ſhulde take himſelfe gouernynge charge hole realme vncles ceaſe gouernynge ynough buſyneſſes kynge thanne paſte twenty yere age openly publyſſhed euery man thought reſonable kynge came rennes feeſt ſayntes helde great feeſt vncles hym fyrſt knowledge kynge caſtyle duke lācaſtre cōcluded vpon peace vpon maryage bytwene kinges ſonne duke doughter frenche kyng ſported duke berrey ſayde fayre vncle ye haue fayled entent nother lyke enioy wyfe ye wolde haue howe ſay therto ſayeth corage duke berrey ſayde syr ſaye nothynge well haue fayled ſhall ſpede ſome place frenche men beganne murmure vpon maryage ſaid nat done without great alyaūces whiche ſhalbe thynge greatly preiudycyall tyme come realme fraūce ſuche conſidred botom mater ſaid howe caſtyle englande portugale one alyaunce accorde theſe thre realmes ſee lande maye make warre realme fraunce wherfore ſayde good kynge ſhulde ſende prouyde remedy tymes conſydringe vnhappy kyng caſtyle hath made alyaūce maner deed man duke lancaſtre man without men puyſſaunce alſo ſayde howe kyng caſtyll ought nat make aliaūce man counſayle frenche kynge kynge maye ſende hym worde wyll make hym lowe varlette hath made hym great lorde lette kynge make warre agaynſte realme caſtyle putte vnhappy kyng ſonne baſtarde lette kyng gyue realme owne brother duke thourayne yet hath great herytage ſhall well ſagely gouerne howe dare kynge caſtyle make treate peace alyaunce duke lancaſtre without knowledge cōſent frenche kynge hath ſo moche ayded honoured auaunſed hym loſte realme puiſſaunce blode royall fraunce nat ben hath well marchaundyſed yet wyll marchaundyſe ſayd lette hym ſhamed diſheryted lette hym haue ſuche punyſſhment may well knowe hath yuell done theſe wordes multiplyed ſuche wyſe thynges conſydered kynge vncles counſayle determyned ſende caſtyle kynge iohan ſhewe hym frenche kynges behalfe well aduyſed take hede dothe nat ſo hardy make treatie alyaunce englyſſhe men duke lancaſtre thyng yt ſhulde preiudyciall crowne realme fraunce haue done thynketh lette hym ſure puyſſaunce fraunce ſhall moche ſette hym backe hynder hym hath auaunſed hym kynge realme ſhall entende nothynge elles diſtroye hym conſydred ſhulde meſſage thought ſoeuer ſhulde ought hardy man well ſpoken ſagely valiauntly declare kynges pleaſure thought meane ſymple perſone ought nat meſſage thre perſones named lorde coucy ſir iohan vyen admyrall fraunce ſir guye de la tremoyle theſe thre take one go caſtyle voyage thynges conſydred ſir iohan vyenne apoynted go kynge counſayle ſayd vnto hym admyrall make redy ye ſhall go voyage ye ſhall haue none letter kyng caſtyle credence ye ſuffyciētly enſtructed mater whervpon ye ſente ſaye vnto kynge spaygne aduyſe well cauſe aduyſed rede cauſe reed alyaunces ordynaunces ꝓmyſes ſworne ſealed bytwene hym v marke well youre aunſwere ye ſhall haue hym counſayle thervpon ſhall take grounde procede farther admyrall aunſwered ſayd ſhalbe done ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe admyrall fraunce ordayned frenche kyng counſayle ambaſſadour go kynge caſtyle howe duke berrey ſente erle foize treate maryage bytwene duke berrey erles doughter boulonge cap cli admyrall fraūce taryed nat long paris made hym quickely redye departe tooke leaue kyng vncles tooke waye burgoyne bycauſe wolde go auygnone ſe pope brother ſo dyde ¶nowe lette v leaue ſpekyng hym ſpeke ſomwhat geffray tete noyre encloſed beſieged within caſtell vandachore fyrſte wyll ſpeke duke berrey great deſyre mary well ſhewed within yere whan ſawe fayled duke lancaſters doughter enfourmed erle boulonge fayre doughter named iane doughter lady elyanour comynges howe ſhe nat father moder ſhe countrey bierne erle foiz great frende coſyn hadde ben brought vp nouryſſhed well entreated ſpace nyne yeres caſtell ortayes without coſt charge father mother erle often tymes hadde deſyred haue maryed alwayes erle aunſwered damoſell yonge specially ſir bernarde brother erle armynacke hadde deſyred haue promyſed myght haue maryage warre ſhulde ende bytwene chalenge lande byerne thoſe promyſes erle wolde nat agree therto aunſwered euer howe coſyn yonge amonge owne men wolde ſaye otherwyſe ſir eſpaygne du lyon ſhewed wolde ſaye howe armynacke myght well repute hym beeſt ſhulde graunt deſyre ſeynge dōmage ſhulde graunt theym coſyn maryage ſhulde ſtrength enfeble hym ſelfe sayeng howe armynake helde force nat right countie comynges whiche herytage mother aunte coſyn boloyne wyll well knowe ſhall mary ſo ſtronge place puiſſaunt make warre herytage comynges nowe none anſwere deed man thus whan erle armynacke ſir bernarde brother ſawe coulde nat come purpoſe long aunte lyued ſayde duke berrey lady ſhulde fayre maryage iohn̄ berrey ſonne ſettynge duke ſente ſuffycient noble meſſangers byerne erle foiz deſyringe hym yuell wyll might ſette aparte euery thynge pardoned tymes paſte myght haue damoſell boulonge iohan ſonne maryage erle boulonge father damoſell dyde therto agree aſſent therle foiz made good chere theſe ābaſſadors excuſed hym maryage ſayd howe lady coſyn yonge alſo ſayde howe whan counteſſe boulonge mother delyuered charge cauſed hym ſwere ſhulde neuer mary place withher knowledge conſent wyſe ſayde myght wolde nat breake promyſe othe ſayd none ought deſyre hym thervnto excuſe erle made knewe well coſyn comynges erle vrgell brother realme arragon wolde nat agree thervnto thus ambaſſadors duke berrey retourned without thyng doyng purpoſe whan gone ſir eſpaygne du lyon ſhewed erle ſayde ah duke berrey coūſayle myght well repute ignorant whan wolde haue enforce myne ennemyes iohan berry coſyn germayn myne aduerſaries armynake bargayne ſhall neuer make ſhall rather mary englande hath ſpoken ſir henry lancaſtre erle derby ſonne duke lancaſtre thought nat greatly diſpleaſe frenche kynge ſhulde none haue yet knowe nat wyll ſhall rather mary pleaſure armynake ſhulde haue agaynſte wyll lyeth leaue nede nat trouble ſelfe mater whan duke berrey knewe certē lie duke lācaſtre ſhulde mary doughter ye king caſtyls ſon̄e coude nat breke maryage wyſe v ſixe dayes ſo penſyue none hym durſt demaūde ayled laſt declared entent thē counſaile ſaid hym ſir ye haue fayled duke lancaſters doughter ye maye recouer another great good ſhe howe ſhe yonge age wherfore nat tell erle foiz wyll refuce cauſe hath lady gouernaunce ah quod duke doughter erle boulonge erle foiz hath refuſed iohan berrey howe name god let v yet aſſaye duke wrote erle foiz ſignifyeng hym ryght ſwetely wolde ſende hym four lordes therle xancere lorde de la ryuer ſir guy de la tremoyle vycount daſſey treate hym haue hym ſelfe maryage doughter boulonge beyng vnder kepyng ſo maye pleaſure deſyred erle ſende hym anſwere writyng hole mynde thentent meſſangers ſhulde nat traueyle vayne leſe payne erle foiz receyued meſſāgers brought writtynge ryght amyably wrote agayne duke berrey ſayeng howe right gladde thoſe tidynges wolde redy receyue ſayd lordes outher foiz byerne ſo erle boulonge coūteſſe father mother lady agreed thervnto retourne whan duke berey herde anſwere right ioyfull wynter ſtyll purſued myght attayne maryage nexte ſomer coude nat bring purpoſe aboute ſhortely knewe well erle foiz man lightly wonne ſure ſhulde haue many delay wherfore duke thought worke wyſely ſent ſpecyall meſſangers pope clement coſyn nere kyn damoſell boulōge pope right ioyouſe whā knewe yt coſyn might highly maryed duke berrey vncle frēche kyng pope wrote therle foiz ſignifyeng hym right honorably aduyſinge hym ſhulde nat vary fro ye treatie maryage therby lynage ſhulde enhaunſed thus erle foiz receyued letter fro party anſwered right well coude diſſimule ſuche buſyneſſe helde party good loue fauour bothe pope ye duke berrey yet nat wyſeſt thē bothe counfayls yt coude knowe perfitely erle foiz thought ſurely ¶nowe lette v ſomwhat leaue ſpeakyng mater retourne ſiege vanchadore ye haue herde hyſtorie ſir wyllm̄ lignac ſir iohn̄ boemlaunce dyuers knightes ſquiers auuergne limoſin beſieged ye caſtell vāchadore geffray tete noyre within coude nat wyn maner aſſaut within prouyded thynges neceſſary vii yere though refreſſhyng without ofte tymes wolde come baſtydes ſcrimyſſhe durynge ſiege many feates armes done dyuers hurt bothe ꝑtes ſo fortuned ſcrimyſſhe geffray tete noyre hym ſelfe auaū ſed ſo forwarde ſtriken baſſenet heed quarell ſo fayne kepe bedde wherwt company ſore diſpleaſed ſeaſon lay ſcrimyſſhīg hurt ben well kept might ſone haue ben hole kept hym ſelfe yuell ſpecially fro lechery whiche derely bought coſt hym lyfe died knewe well remedy dethe playnly ſhewed hym reaſon yuell rule ieoꝑdy dethe hed apoſtumed wherfore counſayled declare wyll make hym redy god ward thā made teſtament firſt cauſed come hym ſoueraygne companyons garyſon ſuche beſt expert armes ſate vp bedde ſayd ſirs derely beloued companyons knowe well great daunger dethe haue long ſeaſon ben toguyder kepte good company haue ben maiſter true capitayne power wherfore wolde gladly lyfe dayes ſe ye hadde another capitayne trewly ſhulde acquyte hym kepe fortreſſe ſhall leaue well prouyded euery thynge neceſſary parteyning caſtell warre bothe wyne vitaylles artyllary thynges requyſyte wherfore demaunde generall ye aduyſed capitayne capitayns metely choſen gouerne caſtell men warre aduenturers ought ſuche hath ben alwayes warre haue vſed haue made warre moche vnder ſhadowe kyng englandes quarell haue alwayes deſyrous ſomwhat gotton ſo alwayes companyons aduēturers ought ſuche deſyre feates armes aduenture ſelfe theſe fronters good countrey frutefull great profyte goton therin thoughe frenche men nowe beſiege v wyll nat endure alwayes ſiege baſtydes wyll breke one day sir anſwere demaunde haue ye choſen capitayne amonge companyons ſtode ſtyll gaue none aunſwere whan ſawe ſpake nat beganne ſpeke agayne ſwete wordes ſayd sir thynke ſurely demaunde ye haue thought lytell wherfore ſirs haue layne bedde haue thought deuyſed sir quod beleue well ſhalbe agreable v cometh rather v ſir ſhewe v pleaſe sir quod ſhall declare name hym meane ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe geffray teate noyre dyde choſe capitayne ouer company howe made teſtament ſo dyed howe duke guerles departed fro countre go pruce incydence fell lande duke stulpe taken priſoſoner diſcōfyted cap c lii fayre ſirs quod geffray knowe well ye haue alwayes ſerued honoured men ought ſerue ſoueraygne capitayne ſhall ye gladder ye wyll agre haue capitayne one diſcended bloode beholde aleyne rour coſyn peter brother men armes blode • make aleyne youre capitayne ſwere hym faythe obeyſaunce loue loyalte preſence alſo brother howe wyll aleyne haue ſouerayne charge sir quod well content ye haue ryght well choſen companyons made theym ſeruyaunt aleyne roux peter brother whan done geffraye ſpake agayne ſayde nowe ſirs ye haue obeyed pleaſure canne great thanke wherfore ſirs wyll ye haue parte ye haue holpen conquere ſaye vnto yonder cheſt ye ſe ſtande yonder therin ſome xxx thouſande frankes wyll gyue accordynge conſcyence wyll ye content fulfyll teſtament howe ſaye ye sir quod right well contente fulfyll commaundement than̄e firſte quod wyll gyue chapell ſaynt george caſtell reparacious therof thouſande fyue hundred frankes gyue louer hath truely ſerued two thouſāde fyue hundred frankes alſo gyue aleyne roux newe capitayne foure thouſande frankes alſo varlettes chambre gyue fyue hūdred frankes myne offycers gyue thouſande fyue hundred frankes reſt gyue bequeth ſhall ſhewe ye vpon thyrtie companyons one ſorte ye ought bretherne one alyaunce withoute debate ryotte ſtryfe amonge haue ſhewed ye ſhall fynde yonder cheſte wyll ye departe reſydue equally truely bitwene thyr tie ye nat thus contente deuyll wyll ſet debate bytwene beholde yonder ſtronge axe breke vp coffer gette thoſe wordes euery man anſwered ſaid sir dere maiſter ſhalbe one accorde sir haue ſo moche loued douted ye wyll breke cofer breke poynt ye haue ordayned commaunded thus geffray teate noyre made teſtament lyued nat paſt two dayes buryed ye chapell ſaint george within caſtell wyll accomplyſſhed xxx thouſande frankes deuyded ordayned aleyne roux peter roux brother capytayns caſtell vāchadore ſeaſon ye ſiege ſtyll endured fewe ſcrimyſſhes made howbeit whan dethe geffray teate noyre knowen auuergne lymoſyn knyghtes ſquyers ryght ioyfull therof douted leſſe dyde geffray tyme ſore douted good ſage capitayne expert warre nowe lette v retourne duke guerles ſhewe fell hym ſeaſon bycauſe haue ſpoken hym meanes frenche kyng vncles brother noble fraunce came entre countrey guerles kyng deꝑted then duke hauyng great domage whan duke guerles ſawe mē warre departed apeaſed duches brabant enemyes reaſon compoſicion made rendre vp towne graue vpon certayne poyntes artycles ordayned bytwene ye duke burgone duches brabant duke guerles thought tent employ ſeaſon go pruce made hym redy gate hym company knyghtes ſquyers owne countrey place vtas ſaynt martyn rode forthe throughe almaygne euery place paſſed good chere ſo longe rode came lande pruce knowe nat inſydence certayne men layde wayte hym feldes ſet ware ouerthewe hym men ſo loſt horſes armure veſſell golde ſyluer ledde priſoners towne ſware faythe trouthe paye ran̄ſomes ſpecially ye duke guerles became priſoner made promyſe pay ran̄ſome ſquyer called arnolde ſurname knowe nat ye duke men ledde ſtronge towne lande duke stulpe whether ye duke nat nat enformed therof whan great mayſters pruce herde howe duke guerles taken commyng countre ſore diſpleaſed therwith ſayd howe mater ſhulde nat reſt caſe ſuffr • ſhulde greatly blame tha •• reyſed vp men departed fro cōnyſbredge came great ſtrength men towardes towne caſtell duke guerles priſon whan ſquyer taken duke enfourmed cōmyng great mayſter pruce ſuche puyſſaunce doughted greatly determyned nat abyde cōmyng caſtell thought departe departure came duke guerles ſayd hym sir duke ye priſoner mayſter ye gētylman true knight ye haue ſworne gyuen faithe ſoeuer go wyll go ye ought folowe nat tell ye haue ſente great mayſter pruce nat cometh hyder great puyſſaūce thynke nat abyde hym tary ye lyſt wyll cary faythe promyſe duke thoſe wordes gaue none anſwere ſquyer toke horſe departed wente place ſtronge ynoughe deꝑtyng ſayde agayne duke sir ye ſhall fynde ſuche place named hym ſtronge caſtell oute hyghe wayes whan gone great mayſter pruce came duke guerles none lette hym ſo delyuered duke priſon hadde founde ſquyer ſurely ſlayne great mayſter pruce retourned connyſbredge duke guerles hym shall ſhewe fell buſyneſſe true great brute ran dyuers countreis ſpecially almaygne takyng duke guerles euery man herde hadde great marueile therof thus whan duke guerles come conniſbredge delyuered ye haue herde remembred hymſelfe howe bounde faythe ſquyer tooke hym remembred wordes ſquier ſpake deꝑtyng thought hym ſelfe wyſe wolde breke promyſe truely acquyte faythe ſayd great maiſter pruce wolde lengar tary go ſquyer faythe ſo determyned thynge great mayſter coulde ſaye nouther diſpenſacyon abſolucyon thyng coude nat cauſe duke abſteyne wolde nedes go ye town ſquyer whōe called maiſter euery man herde therof reputed great valyauntneſſe whan came knowledge frendes kynſmen treated delyueraunce ſo delyuered helpe meanes duke stulpe toke great payne mater howe duke stulpe cōſented duke guerles ſhulde delyuered daunger lande wolde wyſe duke guerles ſhulde ſwere ſcale heyres neuer daye none man hym ſhulde take vē geaunce mater waye diſſymulacion otherwyſe thus fayne departed aduenture duke guerles yere ¶nowe let v retourne ſir iohan vyen admyrall fraunce ſhewe dyde ſayd kyng caſtyle frēche kynges behalfe ⸫ ⸫ ¶howe ſir iohan vyen dyd meſſage kynge iohan caſtyle fro frenche kynge counſayle anſwere kynge caſtyle made cap cliii admyrall fraūce ſpedde ſo iourneys entred caſtyle demaunded fynde kynge ſhewed hym howe burgus rode thyder alyghted lodgynge refreſſhed hym made hym redy go kynges palays receyued maner countrey right honorably loue honoure frenche kyng brought kynges chambre kyng receyued hym ioyfully delyuered kynge letter kyng reed called coū ſayle parte whan ꝑceyued letter credence admyrall called forthe cōmaunded declare entent cōmynge redy ſayd fayre language sir kyng ye coūſayle frenche kyng hath ſente bycauſe come knowledge howe ye ſhall marry ſonne duke lancaſters doughter ſir ye knowe well ye kyng mayſters aduerſary kyng coūſayle haue great marueyle howe ye may entende treatie worlde maryage without knowledge ſaye true maryage chyldren nat withoute alyaunce amyte peace loue sir ſendeth worde ye well aduyſed ye haue done mynded yt wyſe preiudiciall kyng ye realme fraunce therby breke boundes alyaunces hath ben ſworne ſealed bytwene kyng henry father ye prelate noble cyties realme noble kyng realme fraunce regarde well wiſe broken one openly knowen ye ryn church ſentence excommunycate payne vnpardonable alſo indygnacion kynge noble fraunce beſyde haue great enemyes sir cōmaundement kyng counſayle haue ſhewe whan ye kyng caſtyle parte coū ſayle ſuche herde frēch kynges ambaſſadour ſpeke ſo quickely abaſſhed eche loked none gaue anſwere ſatte ſtyll laſte buſſhoppe ſpake ſayde sir iohan ye newly come theſe partes kyng ſaye howe ye right hertely welcome kyng hath well herde vnderſtāde ye haue ſayd ye ſhall haue ſhortely aunſwere within day two ſuche ſhall cōtente ſuffycient quod ſir iohan vyen ſo tooke leaue kynge counſayle wente lodgynge ſhewed howe taryed ſeuen dayes without hauynge anſwere ſawe nothynge dyſſymulacion wherwith ſore dyſpleaſed tyme coulde nat ſe kyng kept hym cloſe chambre whan ſyr iohan vien ſawe coulde haue none exployte buſynes ſpake daye ſome kynges counſayle ſayd syrs ſurely wyll departe without aunſwere douted leſte wolde ſayd ſurely ſo done nat called hym day made aunſwere dyd ſayd hym howe might well ſhewe frenche kynge ſuche ſent hym thyder ſhulde haue kinge caſtyle counſayle maner ſuſpecte nat done wolde nat thynge kynge englande ſhulde breke adnychilate maner wayes alyaunces hath ſworne ſealed bytwene fraunce caſtyle howe thoughe kynge caſtyle mary ſonne doughter duke lācaſtre therby make fynall peace chalenge duke maketh realme caſtyle ryght wyfe generally realme counſayleth kynge though aſſent wyll yet frenche kyng counſayle ought nat dyſpleaſed alwayes kyng caſtyle men wyll conioyned alyed french kynge realme fraunce ſubſtaunce anſwere ſir iohan vien brought fraūce fro knig caſtyle proceded ſorthe duke lancaſtre maryage made amyable peace togyther meanes meſſengers wente bytwene duke laye marcheſſe burdeaulx came thyder fro bayon duches doughter receyued great ioye greatly deſyred fro burdeaux wente lyborne whan trewe certayne tydynges come erle foiz houſe howe kynge caſtyle agreed duke lancaſtre ſhulde mary ſonne duke doughter gyue great landes caſtyle greate nombre floreyns two hundred thouſande noble wherof erle great marueyle knowe well ſyr iohan froyſart ſame tyme erle foiz ſayd ah kynge caſtyle vnhappy hath made peace deed man knowe well duke lancaſtre caſe ſuche daunger nat helpe hym ſelfe kynge caſtyle hathe mette ſage valyaunte prince duke lancaſtre hath valyauntly borne hym ſelfe warre ſeaſon nowe lette v ſomwhat ſpeke army ſee aboute feeſt cryſtmas erle arundell ben longe ſeaſon ſee coſtynge fronters bretaygne rochell xaynton normandy ſo paſſed karenten fore tooke lande chirbroke wolde haue done ſome dedes armes ye ſame ſeaſon ſouerayne capytayns towne garyſon karentyne lorde hambre lorde coucy great nombre knyghtes ſquyers normādy whan erle arundell knewe howe towne karentyne ſo well prouyded furnyſſhed good men warre paſſed forthe ſawe well aſſautinge therof myght rather leſe wyn came nother towne therby called toraguy aſſayled toke perforce pylled wanne great rycheſſe toke theym many priſoners came good towne bayeux came barryers made ſkrymyſſhe none aſſaute englyſſhmen paſſed watch ſaynte clemente dyd great domage countrey taryed fyftene dayes man encountred marſhall blann • uille normandy knewe nat comynge wolde haue prouyded mater whan englyſſhe men done enterpriſe done great domage countrey normandy aſmoche hūdred thouſande frankes came vnto drewe backe paſſed agayne watch retourned chyrbroke dyd put conqueſt ſuretye ſauegarde ſhyppes whan wynde wether ſhyppes charged entred dyſancred toke ſee retourned englande aryued hampton thus army erle arundell ſee concluded ſeaſon ¶howe ſyr loys xancere wente ſe erle foize ortays howe duke lancaſtre burdeaux dedes armes done bytwene fyue frenchman fyue englyſſhe men howe duches lancaſtre wente doughter caſtyle kynge iohan cap cliiii ſeaſō ſir loys xancer marſhall fraūce languedoc march tholouſe carcaſſone knewe well treatye made bytwene duke berrey therle foiz maryage duke bowlonges doughter whome duke berrey wolde haue though damoſell right yonge marſhall affection go ſe erle foyz enfourmed men ortays whan came thyder founde came ſendynge frenche kynge ſhall ſhewe wherfore frenche kyng thā yonge deſyre trauayle neuer ben languedoc whiche great countrey full cyties townes caſteles nygh dyſtroyed waſted duke berry counſayle gouernaūce countrey greatly enpoueryſſhed pylled countrey tayles great oppreſſyons complayntes wherof came kynges eares reaſon newly entred domynacion realme kynge ſayde wolde go languedoc vyſite countrey alſo go ſe pope whome neuer ſene alſo voyage ſayd wolde ſe erle foiz whome herde ſo moche honour large ſpokē thus marſhall went forthe waye departed fro cytie tholous fyue hundred horſe rode ſo longe yt came tarbe bygore fro thence morloys bierne erle foiz ſignyfied comyng ioyfull cōmaunded offycers towne ortays ſhulde well aparelled receyue ſayd marſhals comynge pleaſed hym ryght well lodgynges men made redy erle rode feldes mete hym mothan thre hundred horſes receyued hym good chere ortays ſyre dayes marſhall ſayd erle howe frenche kynge great affection ſe countrey languedoc ſe hym erle aunſwered ſayd syr kynge ſhall ryght welcome gladde wolde ſe hym yea ſir quod marſhall kynges entenſion comyng playnely knowe whether ye wyll holde frenche engliſſh alwayes ye haue diſſymuled warre ye wolde neuer arme deſyre ſir quod erle thanke ye
